title.narrative: Provision of Integrated quality Health and WASH services to IDPs, Host Communities, and Returnees prone to Cholera in Adamawa State.

description.narrative: Operation of the insurgents dating back to 2009 which is still active in three northeastern states (Borno, Adamawa and Yobe) at different magnitude has rendered several population vulnerable aside deaths recorded including property since 2009. It has been estimated that over this period, thousands of people have been affected, leaving them without homes or access to the most basic needs (including Health and WaSH), with more than 2.4 million people displaced of which and more than 70% are women and children. Humanitarian crisis in Adamawa state has lingered for more than 4 years, following the activities of the Boko Haram insurgents since November 2014. Amid this crisis, which has rendered hundreds of thousands of people homeless, other disasters like flood and Cholera outbreak in some communities across several LGAs of Adamawa has compounded the humanitarian situation in the state. Although large number of these population were displaced in the Northern LGAs of Adamawa State, the displaced population are spread across other LGAs they felt safer (including Girei and Song LGA) who play hosts to displaced population. In September 2019, the Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) Round XXVIII conducted by IOM, NEMA and the Nigerian Red Cross indicated that there are 200,011 displaced persons in Adamawa State, with an increase of 7,477 for the data of the previous round. Out of these population, 14,467 are living in IDPs camps and Camp-like settings, while 185,144 are living in Host communities. The report also indicated that there are 808,584 returnee population in Adamawa state. Most of these displaced population are living in host communities spread across many LGAs (including Song and Girei LGAs). The project: Improving the Living Conditions of IDPs and Host Communities through the provision of Integrated Services in Adamawa State is an Integrated Intervention which plan to prevent, mitigate and respond to issues in two interrelated sectors (Health and WASH).The Intervention Section intends to fill critical gaps in the ongoing cholera respond at the first aid level before referral to higher level of care in the affected LGAs ( Girei and Song LGAs), Adamawa State. Also, the provision of Integrated Primary health care services, including sexual and reproductive health, essential drugs and medical supplies in IDPs camps and host communities’ health facilities are to be facilitated. Similarly, AGUF is proposing to intervene in Girei and Song LGAs of Adamawa State under this second reserved allocation through the construction of (20) hand pump boreholes, rehabilitation of 50 dysfunctional hand-pumps in Song and Girei LGAs:, facilitate cholera tailored hygiene promotion activities as part of cholera prevention and preparedness, facilitate capacity building of local area (Boreholes) Mechanics who would help in the maintenance of the hand pumps at the exit of AGUF and partners and also targets the procurement and distribution of WASH kits to vulnerable households. In summation, the intervention is targeting to reach out to 46750 direct beneficiaries.
